Zadnji vrček piva bodo izpili v pivovarni
06 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Andraž Gombač

Odlično besedilo, odlični igralci, odličen režiser ... Velika uspešnica Jez, ki je v režiji Mileta Koruna na odru Male drame zaživela 23. aprila 2001, se bo po 18 letih poslovila z 200. ponovitvijo. Štiri zadnje uprizoritve drame, postavljene v pub, bodo odigrali v Pivovarni Union.



V Jezu igrajo (z leve) Saša Pavček, Branko Šturbej, Igor Samobor, Ivo Ban in Aleš Valič.  Foto: Peter Uhan/SNG Drama Ljubljana

LJUBLJANA > Največja uspešnica Slovenskega narodnega gledališča Drama Ljubljana ima status kultne mojstrovine, ki jo oboževalci hodijo gledat znova in znova. A priložnosti se naglo iztekajo, predstavo bodo uprizorili samo še štirikrat: jutri, v soboto, prihodnjo sredo in še v petek, vse večere ob 19. uri in na posebnem prizorišču - drama je postavljena v pub in nastopajoči popijejo precej piva, tako da bodo štiri uprizoritve v Kozlerjevi dvorani Pivovarne Union gotovo posebno doživetje. Na jubilejni poslovilni uprizoritvi pričakujejo tudi režiserja Mileta Koruna, ki je pred nekaj dnevi dopolnil 91 let.
Veliki režiser je Jez režiral minimalistično, kakor je tudi prav. Vse temelji na besedilu, tu se navidez ne dogaja nič posebnega, v tipičnem irskem pubu se “le” pogovarjajo. Irski dramatik, scenarist in režiser Conor McPherson (1971) je igro The Weir napisal leta 1997 in jo postavil na domače podeželje, v zakotje, ki ga je med piljenjem drame še dodatno raziskal - z direktorjem londonskega gledališča Royal Court Ianom Ricksonom in scenografinjo Rae Smith je šel na turnejo po pubih, kjer so spoznavali zanimive Irce.
In zrasel je Jez, v katerem privlačno priseljenko Valerie (Saša Pavček) obdajo smešno nerodni rivali: oštir Brendan (Branko Šturbej) in njegove stalne stranke v pubu Jack (Ivo Ban), Jim (Igor Samobor) in Finbar (Aleš Valič). Iz šaljivih dialogov se postopoma luščijo tako humorni kakor pretresljivi monologi, anekdote, zgodbice o duhovih, nadnaravnih pojavih, ki so jih izkusili vaščani, osebnih tragedijah ...
“Jez je odlično, vrhunsko napisana drama, nekakšna realistična tragikomedija,” je predlani ob prejetju Borštnikovega prstana v intervjuju za naš časopis povedala Saša Pavček. “Jez je pisan realistično, kar trenutno v teatru ni moderno, a v njem je toliko človeške topline, da očitno gledalcu omogoča identifikacijo.”
Korunova minimalistična režija je zanjo ideal: “Niti videti ni, da bi bilo kaj zrežirano. A je - verjemite mi - režiran vsak detajl, vsak milimeter.” Igralka je v intervju še posebej pohvalila tako prevajalko kakor lektorico: Tina Mahkota je dramo sijajno prelila v slovenščino, Tatjana Stanič pa je režiserju in igralcem pomagala besedilo razčleniti in prikrojiti tako, da zveni naravno, pogovorno.
Izkazali so se še dramaturginja Darja Dominkuš, scenografinja in kostumografinja Janja Korun in drugi, Ivo Ban in Igor Samobor pa sta na Borštnikovem srečanju leta 2001 prejela nagradi za igro.
Včeraj so nam iz Drame sporočili, da je na voljo samo še nekaj vstopnic za predstavi ta četrtek in naslednjo sredo. Morda bo na voljo še kakšna za druga termina, saj bodo vstopnice po morebitnih odpovedih rezervacij takoj vrnili v prodajo.  


Režiser Mile Korun na prizorišču 150. ponovitve predstave Jez, ki so jo v Mali drami uprizorili 30. decembra 2010. Foto: Andraž Gombač
text:
The last mug of beer will be drunk at the brewery
06 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Andraž Gombač

Great lyrics, great actors, great director ... The big blockbuster Jez, which was directed by Mile Korun on stage on April 23, 2001, will say goodbye to the 200th iteration after 18 years. The last four dramas staged at the pub will be played at Union Brewery.



In the dam (from left) are Sasa Pavcek, Branko Sturbey, Igor Samobor, Ivo Ban and Ales Valic. Photo: Peter Uhan / SNG Drama Ljubljana

LJUBLJANA> The biggest hit of the Slovenian National Theater Drama Ljubljana has the status of a cult masterpiece that fans go to see again and again. But the opportunities are quickly coming to an end, they will only stage the show four times: tomorrow, Saturday, next Wednesday and Friday, all evenings at 7pm and at a special venue - the drama is set in a pub and the performers drink plenty of beer so that four performances at Kozler's Union Brewery are definitely a special experience. They are also expecting director Milet Korun, who turned 91 a few days ago, at the jubilee farewell show.
The great director was minimalistic by Jez, as is right. Everything is text based, there is nothing special going on here, in a typical Irish pub they are “just” talking. Irish playwright, screenwriter and director Conor McPherson (1971) wrote The Weir in 1997 and set it in the countryside, which he explored further during the drama - with London Court Director Royal Court Ian Rickson and set designer Rae Smith he went on a pub tour to meet interesting Irish people.
And a dam has grown up, in which the attractive immigrant Valerie (Sasa Pavcek) is surrounded by ridiculously awkward rivals: the keen Brendan (Branko Sturbey) and his regular customers at the pub Jack (Ivo Ban), Jim (Igor Samobor) and Finbar (Aleš Valic). Humorous as well as shocking monologues, anecdotes, ghost stories, supernatural phenomena experienced by the villagers, personal tragedies ...
"The dam is a great, superbly written drama, a kind of realistic tragicomedy," Sasha Pavcek said in an interview with our newspaper the day before when Borštnik's ring was received. "The dam is written in a realistic way, which is not modern in the theater at the moment, but there is so much human warmth that it clearly allows the viewer to identify himself."
Korun's minimalist directing is an ideal for her: “It doesn't look like anything has been cut. But, believe me, every detail, every millimeter is directed. ”The actress praised both the translator and the proofreader in an interview: Tina Mahkota brilliantly poured the drama into Slovene, and Tatjana Stanič helped the director and actors to break down and adjust the text so that sounds natural, conversational.
Also featured were playwright Darja Dominkus, set designer and costume designer Janja Korun and others, and Ivo Ban and Igor Samobor received awards at the Borštnik meeting in 2001 for their play.
Yesterday we were told from Drama that there are only a few tickets left for the shows this Thursday and next Wednesday. There may be more available for other dates, as tickets will be returned immediately upon cancellation.


Director Mile Korun on the scene of the 150th iteration of the play Jez, which was staged in Mali Drama on December 30, 2010. Photo: Andraž Gombač
